article.title: The Use of Naquida-based Superconductors for Stable Wormhole Creation
article.author: Samamtha Carter

section.title: Introduction
section.para: Hmm, what is this? $\forall x \in \Sigma \exists y \longrightarrow \int_0^3$

section.title: Stabilizing the Event Horizon
section.para: And then we realize, it's really a fork()

section.title: Matter deconstruction interface
section.para: Whee, this isn't all that bad compared to LaTeX, and it's a lot more fun, I think you'll agree!

From the above we can clearly see that both special and general relativity were incorrect, and it should be possible to sustain a wormhole with unidirectional travel of fermions (but bidirectional boson travel) with surprisingly limited input energy. Should the event horizon be stabilized by a ring of exotic matter, said wormhole could remain open for up to 38 minutes.

It is possible to use Naquida-based superconductors to temporarially create such a ring of exotic particles to enable event horizon stabilization. Coupled with real-time matter deconstruction/rematerialization technology, this would make travel through these "Star Gates" instantaneous and safe.

caption.para: Timing on the event bus -- everybody climb aboard!
